content: Edited to replace "ii:int" by "ii:long" in the stub (+btw fix one typo).

- I'd say Medium is more appropriate.
- In the example, grid after rotation should be:
dbda
aacb
b#bc
cdad
Might confuse the reader.
- Stub should read ii as long instead of int.
- Can you check the last validator, output seems wrong to me.

Your example test case doesn't make sense to me given the description:
abcd
dcba
ba#d
dabc

abcddcb
1234567
From what I understand, it should be b, not c

No because you always move 1 or you have to move a number of places of the letter in the alphabet as explained in the sentence: -You have a grid of letters, each letter indicates the number of trips to be made according to its place in the alphabet (A=1, B=2, C=3...)
So if you are on "b" for example, you move 2 letters if you are on "e" you move 5 letters...

Yes you are right about the rotation but this is strange because I was sure I had published it without this error. For the level, I will try to ask several people for their opinion while taking into account the level of course. As for the validators, my code passes them all, I take note of your error report. Thank you for your feedback

I checked again for the last validator. The output should definitely be y instead of w.
The process arrives in the start of the loop at the 12th move on (2, 1), that's the letter y. The grid has turned twice counter clockwise and is therefore:
kjihgf@dc
azyxwvuts
qp@nmlkji
gfedc#azy
wvutsrqp@
m#kjihgfe
@bazyxwvu
srqp#nmlk
ihgfedc@a
The loop goes to (0, 4) [letter w] then (5, 6) [letter x] then (2, 0) [letter i] then back to (2, 1) [letter y]. 
12345678912 moves minus the 12 to arrive at the loop that's 12345678900.
Modulo the loop size (4)  that's 0, so in the end, the process arrives back at (2, 1) [letter y].

That's strange, and do you pass the other tests with your code. I'm going to talk about it with other persons, just to know if they meet the same problem than you. I don't understand how it's possible that my code did a mistake just on the last validator, especially the fact that the map of the last test and the last validator are the same and there is no problem on the last test.

Indeed with my solution, all the other tests / validators are green. For the last one, the maps are identical but not the number of moves.
98765432123 moves minus the 12 to arrive at the loop that's 98765432111.
Modulo the loop size (4)  that's 3, so in the end, the process arrives at (2, 0) [letter i].
The math looks fine to me.

Mmmh, I tried on my side tell me if my reasoning is good: I started from element number 215 which is a "y", we know that at some point there is a "pattern" that repeats itself here it is a pattern of 4 elements 
(wxiywxiywxiywxiywxiywxiywxiywxiywxiywxiywxiywxiy.....) when I do (12345678912-215)%4=1 it means that I still have to make a move from the letter or I am as I am on "y" it is "w" no?

What do you mean by "element number 215 which is a y" ? Are you saying you need 215 moves to arrive at the start of the repeating pattern ? Because that's incorrect. Running the simulation step by step, one can see that the pattern ywxiywxiy... starts at 12. In other word the 12th move ends on the y and then every 4 moves goes back to y. Therefore 12 + 4 + 4 ... = 216 not 215.
Then the formula is (12345678912 - 12) % 4 or (12345678912 - 216) % 4 if you prefer and the result is 0 so the cursor will arrive exactly at the same place as the start of the loop, the letter y.
I am curious as to how you get the value 215.

Yes, sorry it's the number of trips to get to "y" and no it's not the beginning of the repetition of the pattern I know, I just wanted to show that with a random number of trips at the end my reasoning would be correct. And yes you are right because if you do (12345678912%4)=0 you don't have to make a move because you are already on "w" which is element 216; ). Of course I don't pretend to say that what I say is always true or that you're wrong, I'm just trying to understand.

I really feel like there is a misunderstanding between us here.
In the 1st movement, we are on "a"
In the 2nd movement, we are on "@" which make the grid rotates so we are on "s"
In the 3th movement, we are on "a"
In the 4th movement, we are on "k"
In the 5th movement, we are on "d"
In the 6th movement, we are on "e"
In the 7th movement, we are on "c"
In the 8th movement, we are on "g"
In the 9th movement, we are on "l"
In the 10th movement, we are on "@" which make the grid rotates so we are on "s"
In the 11th movement, we are on "j"
In the 12th movement, we are on "y"
In the 13th movement, we are on "w"
In the 14th movement, we are on "x"
In the 15th movement, we are on "i"
In the 16th movement, we are on "y"
From 12th and every 4 we are on "y". So 216th = 12 + 4 x 51 we are on "y". And 12345678912th = 12 + 4 x 3086419725 we are on "y".

Hi, I recently created a simulation of my puzzle and I must admit that you were right, if you are interested in the cause of the problem in my algorithm: it is because I had added the value "y" that made "w" obtain, that said I will find out why this problem only intervened on this number.
I see now. I think it should be made a bit more clear that's what you mean.
Yes, maybe I should illustrate it as I explained it to you. Thank you for your feedback.
